<h3>   CLIMATE MITIGATION
</h3>
<p>Climate is the average weather over a significant period. This can apply to snowfall, rain, temperature, or any other weather phenomenon.
The term "climate change" describes long-term changes in temperature and weather patterns. These changes might be organic, but since the 1800s, human activity has been the primary cause of climate change. This is mainly because burning fossil fuels (such as coal, oil, and gas) raises the levels of heat-trapping greenhouse gases in the Earth's atmosphere.<br>
<br>

  Mitigation refers to lowering the risk of financial loss due to the occurrence of any unfavorable event. To prevent unneeded losses, this is a crucial component for any insurance company. A mitigation example is what? Planning and zoning, protecting floodplains, acquiring and moving property, or public communication initiatives are a few examples of mitigation measures.
<br>
Climate change mitigation are the actions taken to reduce global warming and its associated effects.
<br>
<p>Avoiding significant human influence on Earth's climate is the main objective of mitigation. Another goal is to "stabilize greenhouse gas levels in a timeframe sufficient to allow ecosystems to naturally adapt to climate change, ensure that food production is not threatened, and enable economic development to proceed in a sustainable growth.</p><br>
<center><img src="https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcT3Lz-M_ogQ1TuPjg-d245gDH_QzknUYNDIeQ&usqp=CAU" width="600" height="600" alt=""></center>
<h3>Types of Climate Mitigation.</h3>
<p>Avoidance: Means to minimize the impact on aquatic resources by picking the project type, location, and scale that will have the least negative impact while still accomplishing the project's goals. Avoidance is accomplished by analyzing suitable and workable alternatives and taking impact footprint into account.
<br>
Minimization: It refers to the process of controlling how severely a project will affect the resources at the chosen site, hence limiting its impact on aquatic resources. By include acceptable and workable design elements as well as risk-avoidance techniques, minimization is achieved.
<br>
Compensatory Mitigation: Is the replacement or provision of aquatic resources as a substitute for impacts that still exist after avoidance and minimization measures have been implemented. This is accomplished through appropriate and practicable restoration, establishment, enhancement, and/or preservation of aquatic resource functions and services.

<h2>Climate change causes.
</h2>
The vast majority of climate scientists concur that there is actual climate change taking on. There is less agreement, however, when it comes to identifying the precise origins of those alterations. While some contend that the earth is warming due to natural fluctuations in the atmosphere, others assert that humans are mostly to blame for this rise. Others, as is common in contentious situations, think that a combination of the two factors is to blame.
<br>
<h3>1. Natural Causes of Climate Change-
</h3>
When it comes to natural factors impacting climate change, these three causes are frequently cited as contributors:
<br>
<h3>2. Greenhouse Gases-
</h3>
More greenhouse gases enter the atmosphere as the temperature rises. As a result, the ozone layer is decreasing and less radiation can escape from the earth's atmosphere, which traps more heat. The participants may get caught up in a vicious cycle where they feed off of one other.
<br>
<h3>3. Drastic Weather Changes- </h3>
Extreme weather variations can also contribute to climate change. Hurricanes and floods, for example, can seriously harm the environment, which in turn can have an impact on the climate.

<h3>4. Man-Made Causes of Climate Change-
</h3>
The most prominent man-made causes of climate change include:
<br>
<h3>5. Industrialization -</h3>
Growth in development has increased energy production and use, which has resulted in higher-than-normal atmospheric concentrations of greenhouse gases.
<br>
<h3>6. Inconsistent Emissions Controls - </h3>
Standards for emissions control have not kept up with advances in technology. This indicates that more dangerous greenhouse gases are being emitted into the atmosphere.
<br>
<h3>7. Deforestation</h3>
<p>Plants are vital to life on this planet because they take in carbon dioxide through photosynthesis. When more and more trees are removed from the landscape without being replaced, a disproportionate amount of carbon dioxide builds up in the atmosphere and heats the planet.</p>
<h3>8. Agribusiness - </h3>
While supplying the food needs of industrialized nations, modern farms emit significant volumes of methane and carbon dioxide into the sky.
<h3>9. Modernization - </h3>
High volumes of carbon dioxide and exhaust fumes are produced by both the vehicles that utilize roads and the concrete that is used to build them, which raises the temperature.<br>
All of these factors work together to produce "The Greenhouse Effect," in which greenhouse gases keep heat from escaping into space and warm the planet.
<h2>Climate Change Effects
</h2>
Climate change impacts our world in a wide variety of ways, including:
<h3>1. Weather: </h3>
Food production is impacted by the erratic weather patterns. Furthermore, people are significantly more likely to get sick or hurt when there are extreme weather conditions
<h3>2. Plants:</h3>
Plant life migrate upward or inland as the climate warms and the sea level rises. The local animal population may suffer as a result of this.
<h3>3. Wildlife: </h3>
Animal behavior changes in response to environmental changes. The absence of food supplies and the emergence of new predators that were previously unable to enter their areas have an impact on a variety of species. Animals are consequently put in a precarious situation where they must move or perish.
<h3>4. Businesses:</h3>
Huge quantities of property can be destroyed by extreme weather events like hurricanes and tornadoes. Consequently, these disasters cause losses for enterprises.
<h3>5. Increasing Sea Levels: </h3>
Sea level starts to rise as polar ice caps melt. Additionally, to destroying different ecosystems and natural landmarks, this has the ability to uproot millions of people globally.
<h3>6. Ocean Acidification: </h3>
Coral and other marine species may be at risk as a result of the oceans' rising acidity as they take in more carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.
<h2>Five ways to mitigate the effect of climate change.
</h2>
<h3>1. Put a price on carbon.
</h3>
Cutting emissions starts with clear policy signals.<br>
Carbon pricing schemes, such emissions trading systems that cap emissions or carbon taxes that charge per ton, send a long-term message to businesses by incentivizing them to alter their polluting behaviors and invest in cleaner energy options and low-carbon innovation.<br>
More than 20 cities, states, and provinces, as well as over 40 nations, either have carbon pricing policies in place or are getting ready to do so through emissions trading systems or carbon taxes, and the number of these jurisdictions is rising. January saw the opening of Korea's newest carbon market. China saw a reduction in emissions last year thanks to seven pilot carbon markets in cities and provinces, and the country intends to introduce an emissions trading system nationwide as early as 2016.
The single most significant outcome from the Paris Agreement is a price on carbon. When asked about anticipations for the global climate deal anticipated in December 2015 in Paris, President Kim responded, "It will release market forces.
<h3>2. End fossil fuel subsidies
</h3>
<center><img src="https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcSgg0qU3SNxGZHs4GxX1-erm2Cn6FBe0QcpZg&usqp=CAU" width="600" height="600" alt=""><br></center>
By encouraging waste and discouraging low-carbon growth, fossil fuel subsidies send a different message. Countries can reallocate their money to areas that are most in need of it and where it will be most beneficial by gradually eliminating harmful fossil fuel subsidies, including providing targeted aid for the needy.
In order to artificially lower energy prices, around $550 billion in direct fossil fuel subsidies were given out globally in 2013. This accounted for sizable portions of several countries' GDP. But as President Kim noted, "the evidence demonstrates that subsidies for fossil fuels are not at all about protecting the poor." According to studies, the richest 20% of the population benefits from fossil fuel subsidies six times more than the 20% of the population that is the lowest.
It's never simple to reform subsidies. In order to help the poor when the subsidies are phased away, it is frequently necessary to educate the populace on the true costs of energy. Through a $20 million fund, the World Bank is assisting nations with the design and implementation of social protection systems that go along with fossil fuel subsidy reform.
<h3>3. Build low-carbon, resilient cities
</h3>
Setting accurate prices is just one aspect of the equation. Because all development takes place within the context of climate change, creating a sustainable future is a further component.

According to the president, more infrastructure will be developed in the next 20 years than in the previous 6,000. Cities are expanding quickly, especially in developing nations.
Today, just over half of the world's population lives in cities; by 2050, two-thirds of all people will live in cities.
Cities can manage their development in a way that avoids locking in unsustainable patterns through careful land use and transportation planning, as well as the implementation of energy efficiency requirements. The poor can now have easier access to employment and opportunities, and they can also lessen harmful air pollution.
However, ensuring that expansion is financially sustainable can be difficult. According to data, only 4% of the 500 largest cities in developing countries are regarded as creditworthy in international markets. The World Bank Group is assisting cities in strengthening their strategic planning and addressing the underlying financial issues that may be preventing them from obtaining financing.
<h3>4. Increase energy efficiency and use of renewable energy
</h3>
It is necessary to discuss access when we discuss energy. Around 1.2 billion people worldwide do not have access to electricity, and 2.8 billion cook their meals with solid fuels like wood, charcoal, and coal, which are hazardous to indoor air quality.
The World Bank Group is committed to three 2030 targets through the Sustainable Energy for All initiative: achieving universal access to modern energy, doubling the rate of energy efficiency improvement, and tripling the proportion of renewable energy in the world's energy mix.
Enhancements to energy efficiency are essential. Every gigawatt that is conserved is a gigawatt that wasn't necessary to manufacture. Global energy consumption is currently around one-third less than it would have been if energy efficiency advances hadn't been made over the previous 20 years.
In the meantime, the cost of renewable energy is decreasing and becoming more accessible. Nowadays, creating utility-scale renewable energy is often equally or less expensive than building fossil fuel power facilities.
<h3>5. Implement climate-smart agriculture and nurture forest landscapes
</h3>
The fifth area for action includes both adaptation and mitigation. Using climate-smart farming methods, farmers can boost their farms' production and tolerance to climate change effects like droughts while also generating carbon sinks that lower net emissions. Additionally, forests are important carbon sinks that absorb carbon and store it in the soil, trees, and vegetation <br>
NB: Before climate mitigation takes place, there must be climate chang
<h3>CONCLUSION</h3>
We can affirm that in order to reduce climate effects (to ensure mitigation), we must make conscious efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from agriculture, buildings and proper industrial systems.
